pageDescription: An interactive educational tool to calculate and explore the bijective base-6 number system, which has no zero.
liveConverterDesc: Enter a decimal number to see its real-time representation across different systems.
calculatorDesc: Enter two bijective base-6 numbers to see the results for all operations.
practiceDesc: Test your skills! Choose a difficulty and solve the exercises.
prosList: Uniqueness: Every integer has exactly one representation. This eliminates bugs from leading zeros (e.g., 007 vs 7) in identifiers, configuration files, or API endpoints.
Naturally Sortable: The lexicographical order of bijective strings matches their numerical order. This simplifies sorting and indexing operations without special handling.

No Null Pointer Equivalent: In a theoretical bijective-native system, since address 1 is the first valid address, the concept of a 'null pointer exception' caused by accessing address 0 would be fundamentally eliminated.
consList: Unfamiliar Arithmetic: Standard addition and multiplication algorithms need to be modified.
Zero Representation: The concept of zero as an empty string can be counter-intuitive.
Lack of Native Support: Not built into standard libraries or computer hardware.
